item.title: Lines Form as Cyprus Banks Reopen
item.description: Lines formed outside banks in Cyprus's capital, but there was little sign of panic as the island's lenders reopened after a nearly two-week hiatus.

item.title: Nelson Mandela Is Hospitalized
item.description: Nelson Mandela was admitted to an unidentified hospital overnight to treat a recurring lung infection, his second hospitalization this month, sparking concerns over the anti-apartheid icon's health.

item.title: U.S. Flies B-2 Bombers Over South Korea
item.description: The U.S. said it flew two B-2 stealth bombers on a training run over South Korea as part of its war games, a move publicized to demonstrate deterrence as North Korea continues its threats.

item.title: Pistorius Bail Restrictions Eased
item.description: Lawyers for murder-accused Olympic athlete Oscar Pistorius won an appeal to relax the bail conditions imposed on the athlete, including the right to travel.

item.title: Attack Kills 12 at Damascus University
item.description: Mortar shells slammed into a cafeteria at Damascus University Thursday, killing at least 12 people and wounding 20, according to state media and an official.

item.title: Czech Ex-Leader Escapes Charge
item.description: The Czech Constitutional Court rejected treason charges against the country's former president on procedural grounds, saying that since the euro-skeptic politician has already left office there is no point in a trial aimed at removing him.

item.title: Effort to Form Italian Coalition Falters
item.description: Democratic Party leader Bersani's attempts to form a governing alliance stumbled, prompting him to say "only an insane person would have the itch to govern Italy right now."

item.title: China Navy Ships Go to Far End of Claims
item.description: China took navy exercises to the furthest reaches of its claims in disputed waters, near Malaysia, a country that has made relatively little noise about Beijing's recent assertiveness in the South China Sea.

item.title: Total Sells Canada Refining Project Stake to Suncor
item.description: French oil giant Total SA has agreed to sell its stake in the Voyageur partnership for $500 million to Suncor Energy Inc.

item.title: Thais, Militants Hold Peace Talks
item.description: Representatives of Thailand and a Muslim insurgent group held their first formal talks Thursday aimed at bringing peace to strife-torn southern Thailand.

item.title: Myanmar Military to Keep Political Role
item.description: Myanmar's army chief marked Armed Forces Day by saying the military will continue to play a political role as the country continues its transition to democracy.

item.title: Thai Man Jailed for Royal Insult
item.description: A Thai man has been sentenced to three years and four months in prison for selling video CDs of an Australian TV news segment deemed offensive to Thailand's royal family.

item.title: Once-Touted Afghan Force Hits Hard Times
item.description: When villagers rose up against Taliban rule in Afghanistan's Andar district last year, U.S. military commanders billed the surprise rebellion as a potential game-changer. As the spring fighting season begins, it is increasingly clear the uprising didn't live up to those hopes.

item.title: U.N. to Investigate Fraud Claims at Afghan Office
item.description: The United Nations will review new allegations by international monitors of fraud at the Afghanistan office of the world body's refugee agency, the top U.S. official in Kabul said.

item.title: BOJ Set to Focus on Easing
item.description: The Bank of Japan's policy board is expected to use its first meeting under new leadership next week to overhaul its easing program, setting the stage for a new era of aggressive monetary policy.

item.title: Obama Will Make Visit to Mexico
item.description: President Barack Obama will visit Mexico in May for a meeting with his counterpart, President Enrique Peña Nieto, that is expected to take up trade, economic growth and immigration.

item.title: Channeling Mrs. Thatcher in Tokyo, Seoul
item.description: Margaret Thatcher's ideas are enjoying a renaissance in Asia, where the new leaders of Japan and South Korea embrace the Cold War-era British leader as a role model.

item.title: Beijing, Seoul Protest Japan Textbooks
item.description: Japan's latest round of textbook reviews highlighting its claim to contested territories has met with criticism from South Korea and China.

item.title: Cricketer Jesse Ryder in Critical Condition
item.description: New Zealand cricketer Jesse Ryder is in a critical condition after suffering severe head injuries in a late-night assault outside a bar.

item.title: Earthquake Shakes Taiwan
item.description: An earthquake killed at least one person and disrupted operations at some electronic factories in central Taiwan, but the rest of the island was largely unscathed.

item.title: Gas-Field Quakes Make Dutch Shiver
item.description: The Netherlands isn't known as an earthquake zone, but thousands of Dutch residents have filed property-damage claims against the country's largest natural-gas producer after government studies linked a string of tremors in the Groningen region to natural-gas production.

item.title: Greenland to Charge Exploitation Royalties
item.description: The first woman to be elected prime minister of Greenland plans to demand royalties from companies as they set up exploitation activities in the resource-rich nation.

item.title: U.K. Loses Again in Bid to Deport Preacher
item.description: A radical Muslim cleric thwarted another effort by Britain to have him deported to Jordan after a court accepted arguments that he would face testimony obtained by torture.

item.title: Guards, Drones to Protect India's Rhinos
item.description: Authorities in India's Kaziranga national park are taking a more muscular approach to combat poachers who have killed 22 one-horned rhinos in the park last year.

item.title: Spain Says Budget Deficit Is Wider Than Reported
item.description: Spain said on Wednesday that its 2012 budget deficit was wider than it reported a month ago, again raising questions about the reliability of its government budget data.

item.title: Small Nations Stress Distance From Cyprus
item.description: Luxembourg and Malta moved to defend their economic models after Cyprus's bailout turned the spotlight on other small euro-zone countries with large financial sectors.

item.title: U.S. Soccer Could Use a Good Crisis
item.description: A loss by the U.S. men's soccer team in Mexico on Tuesday would likely revive concerns that this side isn't good enough to make it through an increasingly competitive regional qualifying tournament.

item.title: Arise! Arise! The British Are…Acting!
item.description: On big and small screens, the juicy Yank parts are going to people with names like Day-Lewis. How to fight back.

item.title: Maggie Is Back
item.description: The politics and visions of Great Britain's 'Iron Lady,' Margaret Thatcher, are making a comeback among new leaders in Asia, who are taking the former prime minister as their role model.

item.title: In Israel, Sounds of Spring Include Thwack of Paddleballs
item.description: A hard-hitting version of the popular beach game has been kicking up controversy.

item.title: Photos of the Day: March 27
item.description: In today's pictures, a boy celebrates Holi in India, Edith Windsor challenges the Defense of Marriage Act at the U.S. Supreme Court, sand dunes form in the Netherlands, and more.

item.title: Rebuilt India Enjoys Test Revival
item.description: India's cricketers find new batting order, while England and Australia face issues ahead of this year's Ashes.
